posts.com:
>>1314547
It's the responsibility of the person who seeking help to make it as easy as possible to have that help provided. You made numbers up out of nothing. You didn't show working. How I am supposed to know where you went wrong? If you haven't had it drilled into you to show working that's your problem.

But now that you have shown some working.

9.42" is the circumference at C
1 revolution gives a displacement of 9.42"
60 revolutions is 60 * 9.42" = 565"
120 revolutions is 1130"
Now you see why writing 1179 was both wrong and unhelpful. It's close to an answer, not a right answer, but no one can know how you got to being close to a wrong answer.

You might have left them off while typing on computer but in written work you should be in the habit of writing proper mathematical statements including units, especially when you're using funny burgerland units that mean you just don't off by powers of 10. That way you can check cancellation of units properly.

9.42 (inch / rev) * 60 (rev / min) = 565 (inch / min)

565 (inch / min) * 1/12 (feet / inch) = 47.1 (feet / min)

You are correct with the shaft speed of 30 rpm at A. You are correct that the shaft at B rotates at double the rpm of A.

In the absence of any contrary information, we've assumed a rigid system. For a rigid body in pure translation the linear velocity is the same at all points of that body. A corresponding rule applies to a rigid body in rotation for its rotational velocity. Except at the axis where you run into problems about mathematical points which have 0 radius, all points of a rigid rotating body have the same rotational velocity ω.

If C had a 3" radius, it would have the same ω as if it had a 3" diameter because all parts must perform the same number of revolutions per unit time, but with a larger radius any point on its circumference would have a greater instantaneous linear velocity v.

    return n * fact(n-1)

That convention is also the only reason why 0!=1

Let's say you have two books stacked on the table, you turn your back and I'm allowed to change their order. You can expect two results when you look at the books again: they either change order or not. Now let's suppose you only have one book, the state can't change, the book will still be there. Now let's suppose you don't have any book, how many states will you consider after turning back? Well only one state, the state with no book on the table.

By the way, made the safe production ready version of my code above:
[code]{-# LANGUAGE Safe #-}
{-# LANGUAGE NoGeneralizedNewtypeDeriving #-}

import Prelude (IO, Integer, mapM_, print, take, zipWith, ($), (*))

main :: IO ()
main = mapM_ print $ take 10 factorials
where
factorials :: [Integer]
factorials = zipWith (*) (1 : [1 ..]) (1 : factorials)[/code]

I'll try go with shit I watched when I was young. I would say these would be closer to 7-8 than 4 but here you go. These are all based off their english dub form.

Medabots - personally didn't watch this until I was like 10 or 11 I think but I think dub is appropriate for that age range for the most part. There's one episode where the kids go to the bad part of town, and encounter some drunks that the dub tries to censor with it's spoken dialogue implying their possessed by ghost or something. It's comical as an adult because it's pretty obvious, but as a kid it flew right over my head. There's another episode where characters backstory is being from a country in a civil war. Digimon Adventure - watched when I was 5, and the dub definitely got away with some stuff I'm surprised flew back then. Lots of flashes to white when a human character gets punched or hit. lower video bit rate = more compression = smaller file = lower picture quality
higher video bit rate = less compression = larger file = higher picture quality

A high video bit rate must be why the video file is so large.
Different video bit rates will result in different file sizes.
And fyi, audio bit rate has little to do with file size. It's all about the video bit rate and screen size.

The problem is mainly related of how genders are handled with the first person, the gender of the first person is undefined in English while in spanish there are specific marks to point if the speaker is male or female; for instance "I'm a teacher" could mean "Onions profesor" y "Onions profesora" in Spanish. This causes problem because usually the bot is a girl and it gets turned into masculine during the translation. What I want is a way to tell the translator that everytime it encounters the first person it assumes a given gender, for instance:
>Translate("I'm a teacher","female") = "Onions profesora"
>Translate("I'm a teacher","male") = "Onions profesor"

Assuming speccy is just being retarded and your 3080 Ti isn't fake,
if you just took the cheapest compatible PSU on pcpartpicker,

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1315279
>don't judge the monitor lol
The G27C5 does 165Hz.
You really ought to set your desktop resolution at 165Hz instead of 60Hz.
It's a waste of a great system otherwise.

Not only would you get smoother cursor movement and lower typing latency,
a lot of games do windowed fullscreen instead of dedicated,
so they only run at the same frequency as the desktop resolution.

>evga supernova 850 GA
That's Tier B, not great not terrible, but it might be good enough.
To test if it's the culprit, you could try limiting the power of your components.

For the GPU, you can use MSI Afterburner (or Asus GPU Tweak III).
Set the power limit to 50%-75%.

For the CPU, there's usually a way to limit the package power somewhere in the BIOS.
The exact name and menu location differs between Mobo manufacturers and even BIOS versions,
so you'll have to explore a bit in order the find the setting.
Try to limit the power to 65-95W and possibly even disable turbo boost.
It should be somewhere around overclocking or CPU features settings.

Then run a game, or Furmark + Prime95 and see if your PC still crashes.
If it doesn't, I would certainly point the finger at the PSU.

If you're afraid of making those tweaks, there's no danger to using a power limit.
The components constantly lower their power consumption at idle.
You'd just be keeping them from going into a higher power level at load.

Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

posts.com:
>>1314922
Smash Hit - A game where you have no player character and the camera just flies through a 3D world. You have to shoot metal balls to break glass obstacles that will hit you otherwise.

PinOut - A fairly generic pinball game but with some interesting powerups.

Trainyard Express - This is a puzzle game where you have to route colored trains to corresponding slots. You have a finite amount of space on the board, and there are really difficult challenges, sometimes with combining colors to make new ones, sometimes with using the finite amount of space to make trains "combine" so they all arrive at the exact same time. The graphics are basic, but the aesthetic is suuuuuper modern and minimalistic. Easily one of my favorite Android games ever. It's no longer on the Google play store, but you can download an old APK here if you want to try it: https://trainyard-express.en.uptodown.com/android/download

Auralux - Basically babby's first RTS. Super minimalistic game, where your "money" is also your "army". You start with a single planet, and it produces a certain number of units. When enemy units collide, they disappear. When units flow into an enemy planet, the "HP" of the planet drains until the planet becomes neutral. When when a player send enough units to flow into a neutral planet, they take over the planet and it starts producing units too. The AI in the game can be a bit stupid, but the game is always fun or challenging. There's also an Auralux 2, which is better than the first one in almost every conceivable way, but both are worth playing at least once.

Traffic Rush - A super simple game where traffic is flowing into a 4-way intersection and you can either swipe at the cars to make them speed up, or tap on them to make them stop for a moment. It can get hectic the longer the game goes on as traffic flow increases. The ads are fucking awful, so definitely only play in offline mode unless you want to fork over some money to remove the ads.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314941
continued:
Wordscapes - You're given a wheel with a certain number of letters and you basically just drag from one letter to another to form as many words as you can think of. Much better offline because the ads are annoying.

Bejeweled is always great. Plants vs Zombies (original) is always great.

First two I listed are by the same developer and have really nice 3D graphics and good music by the way. Out of all of these, Trainyard Express is probably the best, at least if you're interested in some puzzles that are satisfying to watch and difficult to solve.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314938
>manjaro linux
Use pamac.
https://wiki.manjaro.org/index.php?title=Pamac

It's also worth familiarizing yourself with pacman, the package manager of Arch Linux (which Manjaro is based on).
https://wiki.manjaro.org/index.php/Pacman_Overview

Since Manjaro is based on Arch, a lot of what applies to Arch also applies to Manjaro.
So feel free to peruse the Arch Wiki.

>I have trouble using the makepkg command
That's for building packages.
pamac/pacman give you packages that are built already.
Typically, makepkg only used when building AUR packages manually.
pamac takes care of that for you.
There's also yay and other AUR helpers:
https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/AUR_helpers

>I find "keys" to be pretty overwhelming
https://wiki.manjaro.org/index.php/Pacman_troubleshooting#Errors_about_Keys

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314864

Harvest moon: a farming simulator, time there passes, and the calendar has 4 stations, where you can plant different crops.
Rune factory: same as harvest moon, but with a mix of combat/monster taming
Stardew valley: the western version of rune factory (and with pixelart).
The sims: after the 2, my favorite is the 3, the 4 is for free, but it looks pretty bad and glitched if you already played the 3. You can play for generations in there.
The guild: I like the 2, renaisance, same as sims, you can play for generations if your characters live enough
Mount and blade 2, bannerlord: same thing, a year has 100 days and you can play as your heir (you must have gotten a wife/husband first, and made some babies)
Rome total war: An strategy game, each turn is a month or something like that, and your emperor can die too, and must have a heir.
Civilization: An strategy game, but here there are many "ages" depending how you investigate the technology (I never finished a game, it usuallly takes hours for me to reach modern age, and by that time I got tired/bored)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314864
Dragon Quest 5: you follow the protagonist's life from childhood to adulthood.
Fire Emblem Three Houses: there's a timeskip.
Mother 3: pastoral life gets urbanised.

>>1314662
>secure ftp connection
see there's two different things and you could be talking a out either. There's
"(secure) (FTP)", commonly called FTPS, which is FTP-but-with-SSL-encryption
and there's
"(Secure FTP)", commonly called SFTP, which is SSH's built-in file transfer over SSH additional streams.

The fact that you're trying to use SSH's port suggests you want SFTP, but you need to work out what it is you're trying to do, before you start trying to do it.

I am by no means an expert, but that looks like constant-current to me:
Capacitative dropper (C1, DB1, F1) provides a lowish AC voltage to a regulator chip and associated passives (U1, R1, D1, C2, L1). D1 (and maybe R1) snub the inductor, the chip and the inductor (and maybe C2) form a very rudimentary switching power supply, with the inductor smoothing everything out. The chip could be providing a constant voltage or constant current, you'd need to identify it then look at the datasheet.

>>1313784
>so if you have 6 leds each has 28V approx, more than 500% the max nominal 5V
These COB LEDs almost always have multiple LEDs in series and/or parallel internally.
If 28V is applied to them, then there's probably 6 LEDs in series, times however many strings are in parallel.
That makes it so only 4.7V is applied to each LED.
If 28V was applied to an LED with a forward voltage of 5V, it would blow up instantly.

Big Clive often covers these kinds of bulbs in his videos.
Here's one example: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5HTa2jVi_rc

posts.com:
>>1314401
>they are in series and provides 5V , it wouldn't turn off (because the first one takes all the voltage).?
To elaborate, I think you're going off series* of false assumptions:
- LEDs are not resistive loads, so they don't work the same way you learned that wires, bulbs, resistors, etc. worked in school. Specifically, their "resistance" goes off a cliff when you exceed their forward voltage forward, or their breakdown voltage backwards. This drop is so steep and so sudden that it's usual to do calculations with LEDs and resistors as if the LED is a magical device that breaks the laws of physics and forces a constant voltage across itself. We subtract the forward voltages of the LEDs, then do the normal math on whatever's left
- you said the driver is a constant current driver. This doesn't actually mean it has a constant current because that's not how electricity works, but its output voltage is regulated by examining how much current it induces. So if you added more LEDs, the voltage would go up to compensate, if you removed or shorted some, the voltage would go down. It's the opposite of a traditional voltage-regulated power supply, where the input charge is constantly monitored by a computer to come up with the same output voltage, instead the charge is constantly monitored to produce the same output current. The voltage produced can vary wildly, even second-to-second.

*hoho
